content:
The issue seems to be that you've configured a single outgoing (SMTP) server to be used by the 3 accounts when what you really need is different SMTP server settings for each.

What you appear to be missing is that you may create as many outgoing server settings as you wish, independently of your other mail account settings, by choosing Outgoing Server (SMTP) at the bottom of the list of mail accounts in the account settings, then adding as many server settings there as needed, naming them however you wish to better distinguish them. You can then associate each of those SMTP servers with a different account / identity.
creator: DavidGG

content: Thanks. I do understand that now. But what I don't understand is how to separate them. Where would I see/add the smtp1, smtp2 and so on? Would it be better to delete the 2nd & 3rd accounts and start over? I don't remember seeing an option to add additional servers when I added those accounts.
creator: cgreen82

content: The Outgoing Server (SMTP) settings window has buttons to the right of the list of SMTP servers to add, edit and remove server settings to that list. Is that what you're missing now or do you mean something else?
creator: DavidGG

content:
Somehow I have the feeling you didn't fully understand what I said in my first post and are still looking at the SMTP server settings from your other account settings. Look at the Outgoing Server (SMTP) settings window shown in the following article. That's what you have to use to add more SMTP server settings:

https://support.mozilla.org/kb/cannot-send-messages
creator: DavidGG

content: Having "smtp" as part of the server name or not is irrelevant, they may name their servers however they wish, use what they told you to use for the server name.
creator: DavidGG

content: I really appreciate your help & I promise I'm not a complete idiot but this is all like a foreign language to me. If I need to set them up as different servers, don't I need something to differentiate them from each other?
creator: cgreen82

content:
Yes, but you have other fields for that, namely "Description", where you may type whatever you wish or leave empty if you want, and "Username", which is the whole reason you're doing this, so it can be different for each despite the three accounts using the same outgoing server, and is enough to differentiate them if you don't want to use "Description" for that.

The server name must be the same for all because they're all using the same server, it's the username each account uses to access it that's different for each.

content:
OK, I see what it is that I was missing:

receiving and sending mail will work with cookies rejected. But rejecting all cookies or removing the exception has the disadvantage that when the OAuth token for Gmail access expires at some date in the future, the OAuth dialog will show up and fail again until you accept the required cookies.

So someone might disable those settings, not knowing or remembering why they might be necessary, and then not see the effect of having disabled them until much later, when he/she no longer remembers he/she had disabled them…

I'll keep that in mind for the next time the same happens to someone, which I'm pretty sure now it eventually will… :)
creator: DavidGG

content:
I think the search you described is Global Search (Edit > Find > Global Search, or Ctrl + K), and the behavior you described is stemming.

If you do not want stemming, you can use the following two search methods: 1. Edit > Find > Search Messages (Ctrl + Shift + F) 2. Quick Filter (Ctrl + Shift + K)

Reference: https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/global-search https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/quick-filter-toolbar

content:
It's more likely that your Mail Provider is identifying his emails as SPAM and marking them accordingly. TB accepts the label and deals with the email accordingly.

You could set up a folder in your offline folders and program a filter in to TB so that everything from his email address gets re-routed into it.

Filters can be accessed at Hamburger (top right)/Tools/Message Filters https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/organize-your-messages-using-filters

Given that you have pop accounts, this sounds like Bug 1891962.

There is currently no solid solution, but some users report it helps to increase+stagger the interval check time for new messages for each account, or turn off automatic check for all but one account.

The bug title is Crash in [@ mozilla::dom::Console::ShouldProceed] with autocheck for new mail enabled of pop account, javascript console is dying during console.info()

content:
Does the user name/email address in the 'From' section of your email (1) match the User name in your SMTP Settings (2) and the email address in your Server Settings (3)?

1 - Hamburger (top right)/Account Settings - click on the name of the account through which you are sending the email. On the right is the return email address called 'Email Address' unless you have put another email address in 'Reply-to Address'.

2 - Hamburger (top right)/Account Settings/Outgoing Server (SMTP). Highlight the server through which you are sending the email and the User Name is displayed at the bottom. It can be changed using the 'Edit' button.

3 - Hamburger (top right)/Account Settings - click on the 'Server Settings' under the account through which you are sending the email. The email address is in the 'User Name' field.

content:
Thunderbird doesn't. An effort to implement this got shot down in favor of a rewrite of the mail storage backend, where re-ordering is supposed to be easier to implement. See https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1846550

Alternatively you can give Betterbird a try, folder reordering works there. https://betterbird.eu/
creator: christ1

content:
I don't know whether Thunderbird will ever do this or whether there is an add-on that does, but adding such a feature would have to take into consideration the possibility that changes can be made to the filesystem hierarchy within the user profile folder with a file manager outside of Thunderbird.

The mail folder hierarchy displayed by Thunderbird is currently directly derived from the filesystem hierarchy within the user profile folder. There is no need to store information about the mail hierarchy anywhere, except maybe for searching purposes, and hence no risk of that info becoming corrupt (out of synch). The moment you start having to save info about the mail hierarchy, you start having to take into account the possibility of that info becoming out of synch if changes are made to the filesystem hierarchy outside of Thunderbird.
creator: DavidGG

content:
Whilst I use Windows and do not use Dovecot, I've had a search around to try and find something which you could try and I located the following which may be worth checking out.

https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1764770#c49 https://www.reddit.com/r/Thunderbird/comments/1eykk5b/cant_connect_thunderbird_to_a_local_server/ User said:

  • In config editor, add 'network.security.ports.banned.override' as a 'string' with a value of "993"
  • Then go to Manage certificates->Add exception->XXX.XXX.XXX.XXX:993 - this was able to get the certificate and allowed me to add the exception.

Config Editor is here:

  • Settings > General
  • Scroll to bottom and click on 'Config Editor' button

Manage Certificates is here:

  • Settings > Privacy & Security
  • Scroll down to 'Security' section
  • Under 'Certificate' area - click on 'Manage Certificates' button
creator: Toad-Hall

content: If I've read your post correctly, you've deleted the POP3 emails? They shouldn't exist any longer but you could check in the profile: C:\Users\[Users]\AppData\Roaming\Thunderbird\Profiles\XXXX.default-release in the folder marked 'Mail'. This is where the data files would have been located for the POP3 account. Access the name of the POP3 account and, hopefully, there will be some non-.msf files in there with decent file sizes. The name of the files should correspond to the names of the folders in which the old emails were held. Retrieving the data from them, however, would take some time and patience.

content:
Sounds like you have enabled the 'Tags' column header and then sorted the Inbox by Tags by clicking on the 'Tags' column header and then you clicked on 'Tags' column header again to reverse the sort so now all emails with Tags are at the bottom of the list.

Click on the 'Date' column header and then all emails will be sorted by date. If you see oldest at the top and you want newest - click on the 'Date' column header again to reverse the Sort.

content:
If emails are showing a load of headers and html then try this:

  • right click on Inbox folder and select 'Properties'
  • Click on 'Repair Folder' button
  • Click on 'OK'

BUT...If emails look more like a saved draft which you edit then it sounds like a 'drafts' flag has been set on the 'Inbox'. The easy way to fix is to use an addon called 'Folderflags'. Install this add-on to correct the properties:

  • https://addons.thunderbird.net/en-us/thunderbird/addon/folderflags/

Some images below may assist when installing that 'Folderflags' addon. The first image should help if you actually downloaded the xpi file from the link above. The following 3 images may helps if you want to auto installed from a Thunderbird search and rest apply either method.
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
Try the info at the following link: https://proton.me/mail/bridge Proton Mail Bridge is currently available for paid subscribers.

You might need to upgrade your account to a paid subscription in order to use it. All information is available at the link.

Proton Mail Bridge is a desktop application that runs in the background, encrypting and decrypting messages as they enter and leave your computer. It lets you add your Proton Mail account to your favorite email client via IMAP/SMTP by creating a local email server on your computer.

content: If this is a POP account, you already have them on your PC. If Imap, here are two suggestions: - click account settings>synchronization&storage, click 'advanced' button to verify that all folders can be downloaded - then, click file>offline>download to ensure that all message content and headers are downloaded - then, exit thunderbird, and use windows file explorer to copy from the imapmail folder to the Local Folders folder and restart thunderbird.

content:
Does the user name/email address in the 'From' section of your email (1) match the User name in your SMTP Settings (2) and the email address in your Server Settings (3)?

1 - Hamburger (top right)/Account Settings - click on the name of the account through which you are sending the email. On the right is the return email address called 'Email Address' unless you have put another email address in 'Reply-to Address'.

2 - Hamburger (top right)/Account Settings/Outgoing Server (SMTP). Highlight the server through which you are sending the email and the User Name is displayed at the bottom. It can be changed using the 'Edit' button.

3 - Hamburger (top right)/Account Settings - click on the 'Server Settings' under the account through which you are sending the email. The email address is in the 'User Name' field.
creator: frisée

creator: Mapenzi

content:
Both. It does certainly qualify as a bug and there is a particular reason for it.

Folders in Thunderbird correspond to files in mbox format within the user profile folder. When you tell Thunderbird to change the name of a folder, you're telling it to change the name of the corresponding mbox file in the filesystem. Now, filesystems can be case sensitive or insensitive, meaning filenames that vary only in case may be considered to be different or not. So my guess is that before renaming the mbox file, Thunderbird checks whether a file with the new name already exists in that location, and if the filesystem is case insensitive, the result will be that yes, a file with the new name already exists, namely the very file it's trying to rename… :)

Fortunately, this has an easy workaround. Just rename the folder to something different first, then rename it to the name you want.
creator: DavidGG

content: Thank you for your quick response. The (Linux) filesystem I use is case sensitive. It discriminates perfectly between "stuff" and "Stuff". I have been using the workaround for some time, but it seems a bit clumsy and unnecessary. So I wandered if it could be amended.
creator: ezijlstr

content: Ah! It must be Thunderbird itself that somehow does the check in a case insensitive way regardless, then. It sure can be fixed and you may report it. Don't know what's the exact URL and procedure to do it right now, but I'm sure there is one. It may have already been reported even.
